properties.name: Community Information
properties.webBody:
This Community Information is being issued for Kiamal, Ouyen .

  • There is a haystack fire ong the Calder Highway at Ouyen. 
  • Haystack fires are not likely to spread into grassland but do generate a lot of smoke.
  • Smoke may be visible from nearby roads and communities as firefighters pull apart the hay to extinguish the fire. 
  • Firefighters are monitoring this fire.
There is no immediate threat to the community and no action is required.
This message was issued by Country Fire Authority.

Unless the situation changes, this will be the last message issued for this fire.

Use multiple sources to stay informed: 

  • www.emergency.vic.gov.au.
  • VicEmergency Hotline - freecall 1800 226 226.
  • VicEmergency app.
  • Facebook or Twitter (#vicfires).
  • Tune in to ABC Local Radio, commercial and designated community radio stations, or Sky News TV.

Accessibility:
The following services can help you, or someone you know, access information during an emergency. 
  • To access this information in other languages call the Translating and Interpreting Service on 131 450 (freecall) and ask them to cal VicEmergency
  • If you are deaf, hard of hearing, or have a speech/communication impairment contact National Relay Service on 1800 555 677 and ask them to call the VicEmergency Hotline.
properties.text:
COMMUNITY INFORMATION - GRASS FIRE - Stay Informed
Incident Location: Ouyen
Issue Date: Monday 16 October 2023, 10:40 am
Next Update: Monday 16 October 2023, 05:00 pm

More details at http://emergency.vic.gov.au/respond/#!/warning/30825/moreinfo

This Community Information is being issued for Kiamal, Ouyen .

- There is a haystack fire ong the Calder Highway at Ouyen. 
- Haystack fires are not likely to spread into grassland but do generate a lot of smoke.
- Smoke may be visible from nearby roads and communities as firefighters pull apart the hay to extinguish the fire. 
- Firefighters are monitoring this fire.


There is no immediate threat to the community and no action is required.

properties.name: Advice
properties.webBody:
Minor Flood Warning for the Latrobe River


MINOR FLOODING OCCURRING AT ROSEDALE 

Minor flooding is occurring along the Latrobe River at Rosedale.

Small renewed rises are being observed along the Latrobe River and its tributaries upstream of Rosedale in response to overnight rainfall.

In the 24 hours to 9:00 am Monday, rainfall totals of 5-20 mm have been recorded across the Latrobe River catchment. No significant rainfall is forecast for the next few days.

Latrobe River downstream of Traralgon:

Minor flooding is occurring along the Latrobe River downstream of Traralgon.

The Latrobe River at Rosedale (Main Stream) is currently at 4.01 metres and steady, above the minor flood level (4.00 m). The Latrobe River at Rosedale (Main Stream) may remain around the minor flood level for the next few days.

Flood Safety Advice:

SES advises that all community members should:
  • Never walk, ride or drive through floodwater, Never allow children to play in floodwater, Stay away from waterways and stormwater drains during and after heavy rain.
  • Keep well clear of fallen power lines
  • Be aware that in fire affected areas, rainfall run-off into waterways may contain debris such as ash, soil, trees and rocks, and heavy rainfall increases the potential for landslides and debris across roads. 

Current Emergency Information is available at
http://emergency.vic.gov.au 
For emergency assistance contact the SES on 132 500.
Current Road and Traffic Information is available at the VicTraffic website: http://traffic.vicroads.vic.gov.au/ Next Issue:
The next warning will be issued by 12:30 pm EDT on Wednesday 18 October 2023.
Stay informed - monitor your local conditions and remain alert.
What you should do: 

  • Farmers should consider moving livestock and machinery to higher ground.
  • Be prepared to act if your situation changes.
  • You should stay informed by listening to emergency broadcasters and monitoring warnings.
  • Floodwater is toxic - never play or swim in floodwater.
  • Floodwater is dangerous - never drive, walk or ride through floodwater.
Impacts in your area: 

  • Boating in floodwaters is dangerous due to debris, submerged trees and other hidden dangers. 
  • High river levels and potential flooding in areas close to rivers and streams.
  • Stagnant water can be harmful to your health. Don’t swim, drink or wash in stagnant water.
  • For more information on road closures check the VicRoads website traffic.vicroads.vic.gov.au.
This message was issued by State Emergency Service.

The next update is expected by 12:30 pm EDT on Wednesday 18 October 2023.  or as the situation changes.

Use multiple sources to stay informed:
  • www.emergency.vic.gov.au
  • VicEmergency Hotline - freecall 1800 226 226
  • VicEmergency app
  • Facebook or Twitter (#vicfloods)
  • Tune in to ABC Local Radio, commercial and designated community radio stations, or Sky News TV.

Accessibility: 
The following services can help you, or someone you know, access information during an emergency. 
Community Contacts  (click for community contacts)
  • To access this information in other languages call the Translating and Interpreting Service on 131 450 (freecall) and ask them to call VicEmergency Hotline. 
  • If you are deaf, hard of hearing, or have a speech/communication impairment contact National Relay Service on 1800 555 677 and ask them to call the VicEmergency Hotline.

properties.name: Community Information
properties.location: Culloden, Delvine, Fernbank, Moornapa, Munro, Stockdale, Woolenook, Briagolong, Cobbannah, Perry Bridge, Toolome, Valencia Creek
properties.webBody:
This Community Information message is being issued for Briagolong, Cobbannah, Culloden, Delvine, Fernbank, Moornapa, Munro, Perry Bridge, Stockdale, Toolome, Valencia Creek, Woolenook and surrounding areas.

  • The bushfire at Duffy Rd, Briagolong is not yet under control.
  • Recent rain has dampened fire activity. However, there is still active fire within the area as logs and trees continue to burn.
  • You may see isolated pockets of flames and smoke over the burnt area.
  • Firefighters are strengthening the fire edge by blacking out
  • Several roads are still closed due to active fire and hazardous trees.
  • Smoke will be visible from nearby communities and roads. 
  • Check the VicTraffic website (traffic.vicroads.vic.gov.au/) or call 13 11 70 for road closures.
There is no immediate threat to the community and no action is required.


This message was issued by Forest Fire Management Victoria.

The next update is expected by 17/10/2023 12:30 pm or as the situation changes.

Use multiple sources to stay informed: 
  • www.emergency.vic.gov.au
  • VicEmergency Hotline - freecall 1800 226 226
  • VicEmergency app
  • Facebook or Twitter (#vicfires).
  • Tune in to ABC Local Radio, commercial and designated community radio stations, or Sky News TV.
Accessibility:
The following services can help you, or someone you know, access information during an emergency.
  • Smoke information: Smoke can affect people’s health.  For more information visit: https://www.betterhealth.vic.gov.au/
  • To access this information in other languages call the Translating and Interpreting Service on 131 450 (freecall) and ask them to call VicEmergency Hotline.  
  • If you are deaf, hard of hearing, or have a speech/communication impairment contact National Relay Service on 1800 555 677 and ask them to call the VicEmergency Hotline.

However, there is still active fire within the area as logs and trees continue to burn. - You may see isolated pockets of flames and smoke over the burnt area. - Firefighters are strengthening the fire edge by blacking out - Several roads are still closed due to active fire and hazardous trees. - Smoke will be visible from nearby communities and roads. - Check the VicTraffic website (traffic.vicroads.vic.gov.au/) or call 13 11 70 for road closures. There is no immediate threat to the community and no action is required.

properties.name: Advice
properties.webBody:
This Minor Flood Warning is being issued for Murray River downstream of Tocumwal to Barham.

Minor flooding likely at Barham from overnight Friday into Saturday.

Upstream flows from the Murray River combined with floodwaters from the Goulburn River catchment are likely to cause minor flooding along the Murray River at Barham. The Murray River at Echuca is expected to remain below the minor flood level.

Murray River downstream of Tocumwal to Barham:

River levels are rising along the Murray River at Echuca, Torrumbarry Weir, and Barham and are likely to continue rising over the weekend and during next week.

The Murray River at Barham is currently at 5.49 metres and rising, below the minor flood level (5.50 m). The Murray River at Barham is likely to reach the minor flood level (5.50 m) from overnight Friday into Saturday. Further rises are likely over the next week.

This warning is for communities in Victoria. Floods have different impacts on either side of the Murray River. For information and warnings relevant to NSW, visit www.hazardwatch.gov.au. Always follow advice from your State’s emergency services
Stay informed - monitor your local conditions and remain alert.
What you should do: 

  • Be prepared to act if your situation changes.
  • You should stay informed by listening to emergency broadcasters and monitoring warnings.
Impacts in your area: 

  • High river levels and potential flooding in areas close to rivers and streams.
This message was issued by State Emergency Service.

The next update is expected by 16/10/2023 03:00 pm or as the situation changes.

Use multiple sources to stay informed:
  • www.emergency.vic.gov.au
  • VicEmergency Hotline - freecall 1800 226 226
  • VicEmergency app
  • Facebook or Twitter (#vicfloods)
  • Tune in to ABC Local Radio, commercial and designated community radio stations, or Sky News TV.

Accessibility: 
The following services can help you, or someone you know, access information during an emergency. 
  • To access this information in other languages call the Translating and Interpreting Service on 131 450 (freecall) and ask them to call VicEmergency Hotline. 
  • If you are deaf, hard of hearing, or have a speech/communication impairment contact National Relay Service on 1800 555 677 and ask them to call the VicEmergency Hotline.

properties.name: Community Information
properties.webBody:
This Community Information message is being issued for Loch Sport, Paradise Beach. 

  • Firefighters continue to extinguish hot spots on the fire edge, to prevent any further spread of the fire.  
  •  Fire fighting aircraft will be regularly patrolling the area. 
  •  Please obey all traffic management signage and directions. Remember to slow down to 40 km per hour when passing emergency vehicles.  This is for your own safety and for the safety of our firefighters.
  •  Smoke will be visible from nearby communities and roads. 
  •  Recent rainfall has assisted with fire suppression, however communities need to remain aware of fires near them and monitor for changes in conditions.  
  •  We expect to have this fire fully controlled within the coming days.
There is no immediate threat to the community and no action is required.
This message was issued by Forest Fire Management Victoria.

The next update is expected by 18/10/2023 11:30 am or as the situation changes.

Use multiple sources to stay informed: 
  • www.emergency.vic.gov.au
  • VicEmergency Hotline - freecall 1800 226 226
  • VicEmergency app
  • Facebook or Twitter (#vicfires).
  • Tune in to ABC Local Radio, commercial and designated community radio stations, or Sky News TV.
Accessibility:
The following services can help you, or someone you know, access information during an emergency.
  • To access this information in other languages call the Translating and Interpreting Service on 131 450 (freecall) and ask them to call VicEmergency Hotline.  
  • If you are deaf, hard of hearing, or have a speech/communication impairment contact National Relay Service on 1800 555 677 and ask them to call the VicEmergency Hotline.

properties.name: Community Information
properties.location: Glenaladale, Hunter Corner, Iguana Creek, Walpa, Woodglen, Wuk Wuk, The Fingerboards, Cobbannah, Lindenow
properties.webBody:
This Community Information message is being issued for Cobbannah, Glenaladale, Hunter Corner, Iguana Creek, Lindenow, Walpa, Woodglen, Wuk Wuk, The Fingerboards.

  • Fire still remains active north of Mount Difficulty
  • This activity is within a section of established control lines
  • Firefighters are currently working to bring this fire under control
  • You will continue to see smoke columns from this active edge
There is no immediate threat to the community and no action is required.
This message was issued by Country Fire Authority.

The next update is expected by 17/10/2023 10:30 am or as the situation changes.

Use multiple sources to stay informed: 
  • www.emergency.vic.gov.au
  • VicEmergency Hotline - freecall 1800 226 226
  • VicEmergency app
  • Facebook or Twitter (#vicfires).
  • Tune in to ABC Local Radio, commercial and designated community radio stations, or Sky News TV.
Accessibility:
The following services can help you, or someone you know, access information during an emergency.
  • To access this information in other languages call the Translating and Interpreting Service on 131 450 (freecall) and ask them to call VicEmergency Hotline.  
  • If you are deaf, hard of hearing, or have a speech/communication impairment contact National Relay Service on 1800 555 677 and ask them to call the VicEmergency Hotline.
